ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

comments: Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Robert Buchkowski
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Byungman Yoon
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Rob - he was very helpful, knowledgable and made himself available to us.
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan Yoon
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  My teaching fellow, Rob Buchowski, was not listed in the dropdown menu above.
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan Yoon
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Byungman Yoon
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Byungman Yoon
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan Maynard
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Rob Buchkowski
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Daniel Maynard. He was always available and prompt responding to questions.
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Robert Buchowski
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Robert Buchkowski
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Daniel Maynard
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Daniel Maynard.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan was great. Completing our final project would have been impossible without him. He took a lot of time out of schedule to work with us, and always explained concepts clearly.
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  - very helpful, always accessible and ready to discuss if we had questions.

Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Weakness: Teaching assistants didn't help with course information, only with the research component. Strength: Bryan was very accessible and met with us when he didn't have to and helped us understand concepts.

Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Rob was accessible and willing to help. He did a great job of explaining how lab processes worked and took the time to arrange visits to the isolab while we processed our specimens, which I appreciated and found very interesting. At times there seemed to be a lack of communication between the TAs and the professors overall.
Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan was very educated and organized. He forced us to think outside of the box without directly telling us the answers, which in the end allowed me to learn more.

Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Brian was very generous with his time and was open to sharing information with us while at the same time encouraging us to make discoveries on our own. He met with us several times outside of normal lab hours and was always accessible and responsive.

Instructor: Byungman Yoon  Bryan would not provide us with the answers right away and really challenged us to think through the concepts. Bryan wAs also really skilled at conveying concepts in simplified terms. He was responsive and available when we had questions.

Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan was a wonderful TA! Super engaged, really helpful, and always willing to go out of his way to make sure we understood the material and had the assistance we needed to complete assignments. I'd say he was hands-down the best TA I've had for any of my courses this semester.

Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Rob was very helpful throughout the course. He was good at answering our questions and teaching us both lab and field methods. He also worked with us as we wrote our final report to clarify any calculations or concepts we did not understand.

Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Rob was great. He was very accessible and very helpful. He gave good guidance about how we should approach problems that we had and when he wasn't sure of an answer, he said so and suggested other places we might find answers to our questions.

Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Dan was an extremely helpful TA which guided us throughout the final project field collection, lab work and data analysis. He was prompt in his replies and we were able to schedule sessions to clarify our doubts easily.
Instructor: Daniel Maynard  Open, kind, spent a lot of time with us working on our project.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: - great to have 3 different experts for understanding ecosystems & landscapes in one class which lead to interesting discussions and exploring different topics with the the leading experts in the field. (instructors) - work load is a lot but worth it! (class general evaluation) - Sometimes topics were discussed rather fast (every topic in one single lecture) which was challenging if students don't have prior environmental science knowledge however, this leads to being able to cover a very broad and complete span of topics. (class general evaluation)
Great course.
15- very relevant to people interested in industrial ecology! Should be advertised that way since it is definitely valuable to people outside of ecology/conservation fields.

Response for 14/15: This was my favorite course this semester. I gained a lot from taking it, particularly in terms of systems thinking and coming to terms with the complexities of a system. For the teaching fellow question: I did not have either of the teaching fellows in the drop down, but I had to choose one to submit the evaluation. My teaching fellow was Rub Buchkowski.

I think that the professors individually were effective, and each had their strengths and weaknesses that complemented one another well. However, my biggest critique of the class was that it needed greater cohesion from the outset. There were many moving parts (lectures, problem sets, a textbook, articles, forum discussions, comments, lab work, field trip, group presentations, 3 professors and 3 TAs) and sometimes it felt a little chaotic. It was not always evident how the pieces built on one another or what the major takeaways should be. For a foundations class, I think the professors tended to overestimate the level of knowledge of the subject matter that the class came in with, and this was frustrating for many students. The class also seemed very frontloaded with the workload tapering off towards the end of the semester rather than being spread out more evenly. That being said, I'm really happy I took the course and I do feel like it all came together at the end (I just would have liked to have had a better idea of where we were headed from the beginning).

I struggled at first in this course because I didn't have a background in ecology, but through perseverance and continually working on the assigmnents I was able to comprehend a lot more. I appreciated how this course was designed in terms of assignments and lectures. The professors clearly wanted us to have fun while learning - I am very happy I took this course.

Question 15: I think that the course provide important understanding of ecological concepts and also provoke traditional ways of thinking about ecosystem concepts. The field component also helped us understand the challenges in evidence-based science and understanding the limitations.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field/lab experience was very valuable. A think I will be a better manager having been exposed to the research process. Class discussions and readings were relevant to my area of interest.

- very diverse which I appreciated a lot: fieldtrips, lab experience, class work, exercises, final project - I learned a lot and enjoyed the course a lot! - very good course to understand the system approach and think beyond the traditional thinking on all levels. - cutting edge topics which we were able to explore together - high quality course - critical thinking is demanded for topics that seem familiar to us (what is sustainability, how does the human fit in an ecosystem, etc. ) - this is very challenging and very enriching!

I really appreciated the style of these three professors working together. I liked that it was hands-on, involving lab work and field time. We delved deeply into the topics from the readings and the professors challenged me to think critically about the material.
The complementary nature of the field/labs, lectures and readings. They reinforced each other. It also reinforced what I was learning in the physical sciences foundation, which was so helpful!
Doing the field research was a big benefit as I have never done that sort of natural science research before. I liked the in class student discussions.
It was a very interdisciplinary course.
The lab/field section was great. Also, my group for Marsh was stellar - all working together efficiently.

Field trips are a valuable portion of this course, especially for students who will go on to NOT be researchers. Having this first hand experience will provide a basic background and understanding of the field techniques that go into create the science used in making management decisions. The in class student "forums" were excellent. I would encourage more of this in the future, perhaps with a bit more guidance from the instructors. Being able to debate and discuss ideas helps to guide students toward natural intellectual epiphany on previously unfamiliar topics.

The last third of the class provided a wonderful synthesis of the class material and raised ethical and moral questions related to it. Wish there were more of these types of discussions in other classes.

The field visits and subsequent lab work enabled us to collect our own data, analyze it and gain a deeper understanding of ecosystem processes. We also learned to question existing ecosystem models that exclude humans, and think about managing complex adaptive systems. The professors care deeply about what they do and they communicate that effectively to us. I enjoyed the debates we had in class and the exchanges we had with our professors. This class was well-thought out and balanced independent work with group work very well. It gave us an experience of crafting a land management plan as a team.
Both the reading-based class discussions and the field trips were very valuable.
The assignments helped me grapple with the concepts in a hands on way. I also really liked the Halloween ecosystems assignment
The ecological concepts and the class discussions were interesting and thought provoking.
To work on a scientific project from data collection to the final report.
Learning the challenges to build up a carbon budget after undergoing the sampling and calculating by ourselves

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course felt somewhat disjointed. It was not always clear what we were supposed to get out of each lecture or exercise. This might also have to do with the fact that we had three different professors, but overall I think that was an advantage.
- suggest basic preparation material for people without background in environmental science for the class.

The work load could be dispersed more evenly. It might be useful to have smaller groups for group projects and field work- putting together a cohesive presentation and paper with 10+ paper is pretty difficult. Mark moves a bit too quickly, and talks a bit too fast, when presenting new material in lectures.
A better lay down of the division between professors' parts of the course. And an understanding of why the course progresses in the topics in the order it does.
Professor office hours would have helped as we would have felt more comfortable going in to talk to them instead of having to set up an appointment.

Since its interdisciplinary aspect, I have to struggle to get through a concept that I didn't know well. Although I know its students' responsibility of pushing harder to learn and study, there were a lot going on that was very overwhelming.
More marsh trips!

For lab/ field trip work, more of an organized introduction to how the particular ecosystems function would have been very beneficial. Our professors and teaching fellows likely have a wealth of knowledge about each ecosystem, and I feel like I missed out on that in the course.
I though the course was generally well run.
I think a stronger correlation of field and lab experiments to concepts learned in the class. I was not always aware of the connection between the two components of the class.
The fieldwork process could be better thought through. For instance, we were not very sure what we were up to at the beginning of the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: - the combination of course lector and field trip/lab section was very well designed and helped a lot to understand concepts learned in class.
Lab sections were right on point with course lectures. They provided a practical way of applying the material.
There was a good relationship, and the things from the research were informed by what we learned in the lectures.

I think there could have been more overlap between the lecture and lab. I felt at times that they were almost 2 separate classes. One way would be to have the TAs more involved in both the lectures and the lab. We were told that the TAs were hired only to help with the lab section and not the course material and problem sets, which made the course feel disjointed. It would have been very helpful to have the TAs do review sessions for the problem sets.
The lab allowed me to apply the lecture material to a real world scenario!

Although time is limited, it would be nice for each of the three separate groups (Old field, forest, marsh) to learn more about the other two groups beyond what is presented in the final presentations. I feel like I know a lot about the marsh system, but feel like I missed out on some the basics of the other two ecosystems.
There was not very much explicit connection between lectures and lab sections. If more connections were reinforced between them, the course would be stronger.
Yes, the relationship was very effective.
See above.
Yes.
Good ratio of lectures and lab.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: - very good course to understand the system approach and think beyond the traditional thinking for on all levels. - cutting edge topics which we were able to explore together - high quality class. I learned how science and field work are developed and approached - great pleasure by working on an actual management plan for our final project - I am interested in business and the environment however I believe this class is core to understanding the scientific approach of environmental topics which are very important if we want to integrate environment successfully in a business context.
I'm interested in climate change, and needed to gain a better understanding of the natural sciences driving it.
As I come from a social science background, I wanted to gain more hard skills and understand the natural science behind the policy decisions.

Yes it fits very well although I wished to be explained mathmatical concepts in detail. I worked on problem sets with struggles, ending up with only accomplishment of turning in it with feeling that I don't know about it well yet.
I wanted to take one solid intro to ecosystem ecology course, and this met my expectations.
It was a perfect basis for me to learn all of the ecology terms that was missing a background in.

This was a great introduction on which to build a foundation in understanding ecosystem science and management strategies. As someone who will not likely be pursuing a science/research career, this experience will help me form my understanding of the work that is done in the field, something that can not be replicated from a desk chair.
I came in with little-to-no background in the life sciences. This was a fantastic crash course they quickly laid the foundation for a career in the environmental sciences.
This course provides the foundation for ecosystem processes and land management that I will need for my future studies in natural resource management.

I come from a social science background and am trying to increase my knowledge in ecology and other hard sciences. This course was a very good introduction to biogeological cycling and the way natural and human systems fit together, and the implications of this relationship for management.

This course provided a fantastic foundation with which to approach the rest of my fes degree. I am thrilled to have a better understanding of the carbon and nitrogen cycles. I think the concepts I learned will apply to the rest of my mf degree.
I don't have a background in ecology and provided an overview that would help me relate to planning of public spaces within green field sites.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It seemed essential to my interest in ecosystem conservation and management.

- understand the dynamics in an ecosystem and the role humans play in it. - it was my first environmental science class coming from a background of international relations (policy & law) and thus at the beginning the course was very challenging to understand all the new concepts. The class is a high-level course to explore the topics of ecosystem & human interaction. Definitely an important core class to have done!

I wanted to gain a better understanding of the carbon cycle, and I certainly achieved that. I also gained a lot more in terms of understanding the complexities of ecosystems and the intervention points for management.
I wanted a background in ecology.
See question 20.
I wanted to learn overarching concepts on nutrient cycling across landscapes
To learn basic ecological concepts and cycles.
It was between this and physical science with Shimmy. I like that this course had three perspectives to offer students.
To establish a basic understanding of the life sciences and the questions it presents going forward.
I had heard good things about this course from even before I was admitted to FES. The fieldwork element was a big draw as well.
See answer to question 20.
To get a baseline understanding of ecology concepts.
See above.
Want to know how the concept of natural ecosystem can be applied in industries

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
yes very much so.
yes
Yes, and this was my favorite class!
Yes
Yes!

My understanding and comprehension of the topics covered expanded greatly. I am able to apply many of the principles I learned in this class to other courses, and really, other areas of my life. The idea of trophic cascades and understanding unintended consequences really encourages people to take a system-level view of any problem they approach and not just think about singular cause and effect.
Yes.
Yes, and more.
Yes.
And more! Loved the energy and thoughtfulness the professors brought to the class. Truly cool to see how much I learned. Thank you!
Yes.
Yes, it exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Our project groups were quite large. I might have gotten more out of the final project had our groups been half the size, but overall I think working as part of a group was beneficial.
- great opportunity to explore different topics together in a group - in the end we had a real community feeling within the whole classroom.
It was great to bounce ideas off of each other and to split up the work, but it was challenging to coordinate everyone's schedules and to write a cohesive paper/presentation as a group.
I liked the small group projects in class and reading discussions. They broke up the leacture format nicely.

Disadvantage: My group was too big (10 people) so coordinating was hard. This meant that we didn't have to do everything, which was good, but we didn't learn as much as we could. Advantages: Had to do less work, so could focus on it. We never could have done the management plan on our own. You could learn from other people in your group.
The advantages: I can learn from collegues Meetings helped me to be more engaged to the course The disadvantages: Time consuming in setting a meeting
Our group worked extremely well together. In my opinion, there were no disadvantages in this class.

Our group of 10-11 people was unwieldy. It is tough to manage this many people, but I think we did an alright job of it anyway. It also becomes easy for people to free-ride and for others to dominate assignments, perhaps infringing on the learning objectives of others in the process. That said, our group work very well together and I think that we were all proud of our final product and improved understanding of the ecosystems we studied.

Due to field trips in other courses, some team members did more work than other team members. We tried to even it out during the analysis portion of the lab work, but this was difficult since team members that were most often present best understood the data to be analyzed.

We wrote a land management paper together as a group based on the field data we collected and the analysis we did. It gave us the experience of working together on land management as a team, which is usually how it is done in a professional setting.

Advantages: It was good to work through complex ideas and problems together. It helped to solidify understanding of the concepts taught in class. Disadvantages: Groups were large for the final project and it was sometimes difficult to coordinate such large groups of people. Thankfully, google docs exist.
I could not have asked for a better team. Each team project went smoothly and I learned a ton from my teammates.

I think the group of 7 people were too large and it was difficult to come together in terms of scheduling. It was also difficult to put the final paper together and we were only able to focus on certain areas of the paper which is a pity. The large group allowed work to be divided which would otherwise be overwhelming consideration the extent of the final report.
Good amount of team mates (7)

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would advise taking it, but warn them that it is a large time commitment.

For students not yet very familiar with ecosystem science, it is good to do the readings, which are a very good selection for the topics addressed, before hand and actively interact and ask questions. The pace of the course can seem very fast if the concepts are completely new. The class demands a certain amount of work, but worth it. Again, revising actively the material throughout the semester helps to understand the concepts and get familiar with new them.
Take it! Prepare for a few EARLY morning field trips, but they're fun and they taper off as the semester goes on.
Take it! It puts all the pieces together.
Do the readings, they really help back up the professors and give good examples and tie everything together. You get as much out of this course as you put in, so make the effort.
A lot of group activities may be fun but tricky in terms of allocating your time
Take it!
Take chances, make mistakes, get messy!. Do the readings, engage in the classroom, and dive-in to the field trips. (Plus, all the coffee you can drink on Friday mornings...what's not to like. )
While the readings aren't necessary to succeed in the course, they provide a much deeper understanding of the course material.
Take it. It is a great learning experience.
This course is a lot of work but very worthwhile. I found it very informative and I think I will carry what I learned from it into my future career.
Take it and be patient. The work you put in will payoff in spades towards the end of the semester.
This is a great course to take for its exposure and the opportunity to work at the field.
Participate in all field trips.
